threat_description: HNDL attack on transaction records: Adversaries capture encrypted SWIFT messaging, interbank transfers, and transaction records retained for 7+ years for future quantum decryption. Estimated $2-3.3 trillion GDP at risk from Fedwire disruption alone.
main_source: US Treasury FAQ on Financial Sector Quantum Risks

threat_description: Digital signature forgery on long-term contracts: Mortgages, loan agreements, and financial instruments with multi-decade validity periods become repudiable when RSA/ECDSA signatures can be forged.
HSM backup key extraction: Master encryption keys wrapped with RSA in HSM backup archives become recoverable, exposing entire key hierarchies protecting decades of financial data.
crypto_at_risk: RSA key wrapping, ECDH key agreement

threat_description: Core banking authentication bypass: Quantum compromise of RSA/ECDSA certificates enabling unauthorized access to core banking systems and mainframe environments.

BIS Project Leap / SWIFT quantum migration challenge: Central banks and SWIFT implementing quantum-safe protocols for $5+ trillion daily transactions. Phase 2 launched July 2025 with Bank of Italy, France, Germany, and Nexi.

Cryptography Bill of Materials (C-BOM) inventory gaps: Financial institutions lacking comprehensive cryptographic asset inventories required for PQC migration. IBM estimates 15,000+ cryptographic endpoints per major bank.
Harvest-now-decrypt-later on long-lived financial records: Attackers exfiltrating encrypted transactional data, regulatory archives, and market infrastructure logs for future quantum decryption.

PIN block DUKPT vulnerability: Triple-DES DUKPT base derivation keys protecting PIN blocks face quantum compromise; AES-256 DUKPT provides quantum-resistant alternative but millions of terminals require updates.
EMV offline authentication forgery: 90% of global card-present transactions use EMV with RSA as only approved asymmetric algorithm. Quantum forgery enables counterfeit card acceptance.
Card personalization key compromise: RSA-wrapped key injection keys for personalization bureaus become vulnerable, enabling fraudulent card production at scale.
Tokenization backend compromise: Payment tokenization services protecting stored credentials vulnerable through TLS certificate and HSM key compromise.
Protocol downgrade attack: Forcing fallback to quantum-vulnerable cipher suites during payment terminal TLS negotiation.
crypto_at_risk: TLS 1.2 cipher suites, RSA key exchange

threat_description: Terminal supply chain firmware attack: Quantum forgery of code signing certificates enabling malicious firmware injection into payment terminals.
HNDL on classified data: TOP SECRET information requiring 25-75+ year protection is actively harvested for future quantum decryption. Current encryption provides no protection against this threat.
HSM backup key extraction for national security systems: Federal PKI root keys, military encryption keys, and NSS credentials recoverable from archived backups.
Federal PKI signature forgery: Quantum-enabled impersonation of federal systems and fraudulent certificate issuance affecting government-wide trust.
CAC/PIV card authentication compromise: Millions of deployed Common Access Cards and Personal Identity Verification credentials become forgeable.
Nuclear command and control manipulation: NC3 systems with 50+ year lifecycles face highest-consequence quantum threat scenarios.
Protocol downgrade on classified networks: Forcing fallback to vulnerable algorithms during VPN/TLS negotiation on classified systems.
Five Eyes interoperability challenges: Cross-border PKI and encrypted communications require coordinated PQC migration across allied nations.
Defense supply chain firmware attack: Quantum forgery of firmware signing enables malicious code in military systems and weapons platforms.
Satellite communication interception: Military and intelligence satellite uplink/downlink communications vulnerable to quantum decryption. Space-based QKD deployment ongoing but limited.
GNSS jamming and PNT disruption: GPS/Galileo signals vulnerable to spoofing. Quantum sensing threatens stealth capabilities. UK investing Â£8M in quantum navigation systems.

HNDL on patient records: Healthcare data has lifetime sensitivity; genomic data and mental health records remain sensitive indefinitely. HIPAA mandates 6+ year retention but records persist 25+ years.
Connected medical device cryptographic failure: FDA recalls affected 465,000+ pacemakers; devices with 10-20 year lifecycles will operate when CRQCs arrive.
Drug supply chain authentication compromise: DSCSA serialization integrity vulnerable to quantum-forged verification responses enabling counterfeit drug infiltration.
main_source: FDA Drug Supply Chain Security Act

threat_description: Clinical trial data integrity attack: Pharmaceutical IP worth billions exposed; trial data sensitivity persists through 20+ year patent lifecycles.
Health Information Exchange protocol compromise: HL7 FHIR and other HIE protocols using TLS/OAuth vulnerable to session interception and credential theft.
Femtech and reproductive health data exposure: Women's health apps and fertility tracking devices storing highly sensitive reproductive data for decades. Q-Day threatens permanent privacy loss.
Medical device supply chain attacks: Custom ASIC and semiconductor supply chain for medical devices vulnerable to backdoor insertion and firmware compromise.
FDA PQC compliance timeline: Medical devices must align with NIST standards by 2030 per FDA guidance. Devices with 10-20 year lifecycles being deployed now will be vulnerable.

Healthcare data breach quantum threat: 677 major breaches in 2024 compromising 182M+ records. Only 4% of sensitive healthcare cloud data properly encrypted. Thales 2025 report shows 58% evaluating PQC.
HNDL on subscriber data: Mobile network operators retain call detail records, location data, and encrypted communications for 2-10 years. 5G user data encrypted with vulnerable algorithms.
SIM card and eSIM authentication compromise: Millions of SIM cards using RSA-2048 or weaker; eSIM remote provisioning vulnerable to quantum attacks.
HSM key extraction in mobile networks: HSM root keys protecting A5/3, Milenage, and IMS security become vulnerable.
Roaming agreement encryption failure: Inter-carrier roaming agreements and SS7/Diameter signaling vulnerable to quantum interception.
5G network slice isolation compromise: Network slicing authentication and isolation mechanisms vulnerable. Critical for enterprise, IoT, and emergency services.
RAN and core network encryption failure: Radio Access Network and Evolved Packet Core encryption vulnerable. GSMA Post-Quantum Telco Network Taskforce established 2025.
6G security preparedness gap: 6G standards development (2025-2030) must incorporate PQC from design phase. Legacy crypto-agility lessons from 5G transition.
Telecom supply chain compromise: Network equipment firmware and software updates vulnerable to quantum signature forgery. Vendor ecosystem coordination required.
SCADA system authentication bypass: Industrial control systems in power generation, transmission, and distribution using RSA-2048 or weaker.
Smart grid AMI network compromise: 1+ billion smart meters globally must upgrade to PQC by 2035. UK has 38M vulnerable meters requiring replacement or firmware updates.
Energy trading platform manipulation: Wholesale energy markets and derivatives trading vulnerable through TLS and digital signature compromise.
Pipeline and oil/gas SCADA vulnerability: Natural gas, oil, and water pipeline control systems with 20-30 year equipment lifecycles.
Renewable energy DER management compromise: Distributed Energy Resources (solar, wind, battery storage) management systems vulnerable.
Nuclear facility cybersecurity failure: Digital instrumentation and control systems at nuclear power plants with 60+ year operating licenses.
Cross-border energy infrastructure coordination: International power grids and gas pipelines require coordinated PQC migration across multiple jurisdictions.
Aircraft avionics cryptographic failure: ARINC 664 (AFDX) network security and aircraft systems with 30-40 year service lives vulnerable.
Air traffic control authentication bypass: ADS-B, Mode S, and ATC systems vulnerable to spoofing and replay attacks via quantum compromise.
Aircraft maintenance and supply chain compromise: MRO digital records, aircraft logs, and maintenance systems vulnerable to data manipulation.
In-flight connectivity and entertainment compromise: Passenger and crew Wi-Fi, IFE systems, and SATCOM vulnerable to interception.
Unmanned aerial systems (UAS) control link compromise: Drone command and control, autonomous navigation, and swarm communications vulnerable.
Space segment communication interception: Commercial and military satellites, ground stations, and inter-satellite links vulnerable to quantum attacks.
EuroQCI deployment challenges: European Quantum Communication Infrastructure securing air traffic control, aerospace, and critical infrastructure by 2025-2028.
V2X communication compromise: Vehicle-to-Vehicle, Vehicle-to-Infrastructure communications vulnerable. 12+ year vehicle lifecycle exposure.
OTA firmware update forgery: Over-the-Air update mechanisms vulnerable to quantum signature forgery enabling malicious code injection.
Connected car backend infrastructure: Telematics, fleet management, and cloud services vulnerable through TLS and certificate compromise.
In-vehicle network security failure: CAN bus, LIN, FlexRay, Ethernet backbone vulnerable as crypto-agility limited in embedded ECUs.
Digital key and keyless entry compromise: NFC, BLE, and UWB-based digital key systems vulnerable to relay and quantum attacks.
EV charging infrastructure authentication: ISO 15118 Plug & Charge and grid-to-vehicle authentication vulnerable.
Autonomous vehicle sensor fusion manipulation: LIDAR, radar, camera fusion and HD map authentication vulnerable to quantum forgery.
Vehicle supply chain and manufacturing: Smart factory, production line security, and vehicle identity provisioning vulnerable.
IoT device authentication and provisioning: Billions of constrained devices with limited crypto-agility. Average risk score increased 33% in 2025 per Forescout.
Smart home ecosystem compromise: 18+ billion IoT devices globally with weak or default credentials and unpatched firmware.
Industrial IoT and IIoT SCADA: Manufacturing sensors, predictive maintenance, and factory automation vulnerable. IIoT breach cost $4.97M in 2024.
IoT firmware supply chain attacks: Constrained devices using ESP32, ARM Cortex-M unable to support full PQC. Supply chain backdoors during manufacturing.
Smart city infrastructure vulnerability: Traffic management, public safety cameras, environmental sensors, and municipal systems.
Wearables and health monitoring devices: Fitness trackers, medical wearables, elderly care systems transmitting sensitive health data.
IoT edge computing gateway compromise: Edge gateways aggregating data from thousands of sensors become high-value targets.
Smart meter quantum vulnerability: 1 billion+ smart meters globally require PQC upgrade by 2035. Many lack OTA update capability requiring physical replacement.
Multi-cloud cryptographic complexity: Organizations using 5+ key managers and fragmented tools. 45% failed compliance audits per Thales 2025 report.
Hyperscaler quantum co-processor isolation: Multi-tenant quantum computers vulnerable to QubitVise crosstalk attacks. 5% of Tier-4 data centers to host quantum by 2032.
Cloud HSM and key management compromise: Cloud-hosted HSMs and KMS services vulnerable. Vendor lock-in complicates PQC migration.
Serverless and container security: Function-as-a-Service and containerized workloads with embedded secrets and API keys vulnerable.
Cloud backup and disaster recovery: Air-gapped backups and long-term archival storage vulnerable to harvest-now-decrypt-later.
API security at scale: 34% of organizations manage 500+ APIs. Only 15% find DevSecOps secrets management highly effective.
Cloud database encryption: 96% of healthcare cloud data not properly encrypted. Multi-cloud and hybrid deployments complicate key management.
Quantum entropy as a service: True random number generation from quantum hardware becoming commercial offering. Security implications of shared quantum randomness.
Actuarial model and claims data exposure: Insurance pricing models, underwriting algorithms, and decades of claims history vulnerable.
Telematics and usage-based insurance: Connected car data, wearable health data, and IoT sensors feeding insurance platforms.
Reinsurance and cat modeling: Catastrophe models and reinsurance treaties with multi-year duration vulnerable to data manipulation.
Digital identity verification and fraud detection: e-KYC, identity verification, and anti-fraud AI systems vulnerable to quantum attacks.
Parametric insurance and smart contracts: Blockchain-based parametric insurance and automated claims settlement vulnerable.
E-commerce payment gateway compromise: Point-of-sale encryption, online checkout, and payment processor communications vulnerable.
Customer data and CRM breach: Loyalty program data, purchase history, and PII stored for marketing vulnerable to quantum decryption.
Supply chain and inventory systems: RFID, warehouse management, and supplier portals vulnerable to data manipulation.
Omnichannel and mobile commerce: Mobile apps, in-store beacons, and omnichannel customer tracking vulnerable.
Third-party marketplace security: Integration with Amazon, eBay, Shopify and other platforms creates cryptographic dependencies.
Global supply chain visibility platforms: Track-and-trace, customs documentation, and multi-party logistics platforms vulnerable.
Cold chain and pharmaceutical logistics: Temperature monitoring, pharma serialization, and controlled substance tracking vulnerable.
Maritime and container tracking: AIS, port systems, and container IoT vulnerable. 90% of world trade moves by sea.
Warehouse automation and robotics: Automated warehouses, AMRs, and AGV fleets with embedded crypto and limited upgrade paths.
Supplier portal and B2B integration: Multi-tier supplier networks, contract management, and procurement platforms vulnerable.
Code signing and software supply chain: Open source repositories, package managers, and CI/CD pipelines vulnerable to quantum signature forgery.
Software licensing and DRM: License verification, entitlement management, and software activation vulnerable.
SaaS authentication and SSO: Enterprise SSO, SAML, OAuth 2.0, and OIDC vulnerable. FIDO2 needs PQC upgrade.
Container registry and image signing: Docker, Kubernetes, and container supply chain vulnerable via signature forgery.
DevOps secrets management: CI/CD pipelines, infrastructure-as-code, and deployment automation with embedded credentials.
Open source cryptographic libraries: OpenSSL 3.5 released April 2025 with PQC. Libsodium and others lagging. Widespread dependency risk.
Certificate Authorities and PKI: Public CA infrastructure must migrate to PQC. Browser and OS trust store updates required.
Content encryption and studio IP: Master keys protecting unreleased films, streaming libraries, and production assets with decades of value.
DRM HSM backup key extraction: Master keys protecting entire studio content libraries worth billions recoverable from backups.
Content license signature forgery: DRM license servers using RSA/ECDSA enabling unauthorized content access.
Conditional Access System key compromise: DVB-CSA with 48-64 bit security already marginal; ECM encryption vulnerable.
Content manipulation and unauthorized distribution: Decrypted content enabling mass piracy and modification.
DRM supply chain TEE/OEMCrypto attack: Trusted Execution Environment and OEMCrypto implementations with limited crypto agility.
Protocol downgrade during content acquisition: Forcing use of weaker cryptography during license acquisition.
Crypto agility challenges for embedded devices: Set-top boxes and smart TVs with 7-10 year lifecycles and limited update capability.
Long-term document signature validity collapse: Legal documents require 50-100+ year validity. Property deeds and constitutional documents lose legal standing when signatures forgeable.
QTSP root key compromise: Qualified Trust Service Providers issue certificates with legal equivalence to handwritten signatures under eIDAS. Root compromise invalidates entire ecosystem.
Timestamping service retroactive forgery: PAdES-B-LTA long-term validation chains undermined. Forged timestamps enable backdating documents and creating false evidence.
Court electronic evidence repudiation: Defense attorneys can challenge digitally signed evidence as potentially forged, introducing reasonable doubt.
Land registry and property record tampering: Foundational property records requiring perpetual validity vulnerable to signature forgery.
Remote Online Notarization identity fraud: Notary certificates across 47 US states becoming forgeable.
EUDI Wallet cryptographic compromise: EU Digital Identity Wallet (2026 deployment) depends on current PKI. WSCD (wallet secure cryptographic device) keys vulnerable.
Legacy document management system agility: Enterprise DMS with embedded cryptography and limited upgrade paths.
Bitcoin ECDSA transaction hijacking: ~$718B in quantum-vulnerable addresses with exposed public keys. Early P2PK addresses including Satoshi's ~1.1M BTC permanently vulnerable.
Ethereum account compromise: All accounts that have transacted have exposed public keys. Vitalik estimates 20% probability of cryptographic compromise before 2030. BLS12-381 also vulnerable.
Smart contract signature dependency: DeFi protocols, DAOs, and NFT marketplaces using ecrecover. Immutable contracts cannot be upgraded without governance mechanisms.
Cryptocurrency custody HSM compromise: Institutional custody managing billions in assets. $1.5B ByBit hack (2025) demonstrates active targeting.
MPC threshold signature vulnerability: Threshold ECDSA schemes for custody and key management becoming insecure.
Hardware wallet private key extraction: Ledger, Trezor using secp256k1 with limited crypto agility.
Blockchain immutability with vulnerable crypto: Historical transaction signatures permanently embedded and becoming forgeable.
Multi-signature wallet compromise: 2-of-3, 3-of-5 and other multi-sig schemes using ECDSA becoming bypassable.
Layer 2 and rollup security: Optimistic and ZK-rollups using ECDSA for state commitments and fraud proofs vulnerable.

Harvest Now Decrypt Later (HNDL) attacks targeting long-lived financial data including transaction records and settlement logs. Federal Reserve research confirms cryptocurrency networks face permanent data privacy risks from HNDL even with future PQC deployment.
main_source: Federal Reserve Board FEDS Paper September 2025

threat_description: FS-ISAC crypto-procrastination warning: Financial sector organizations have not defined or allocated resources for quantum-resistant projects, compressing migration into unrealistically short timeframes with potential roadmap collapse by 2030.
crypto_at_risk: RSA, ECC, TLS 1.2/1.3 key exchange, PKI certificates

threat_description: CISA PQC product category list deadline December 2025 followed by approved products list. Vendors without PQC roadmaps risk exclusion from federal procurement per June 2025 Executive Order requirements.
pqc_replacement: FIPS 140-3 validated PQC modules, CMVP-certified implementations

threat_description: Power grid SCADA/ICS quantum vulnerability identified in University of Toronto research project (CA$1.45M grant). Grid controllers, smart meters, and energy routers face real-time attack scenarios once cryptographically-relevant quantum computers available.
crypto_at_risk: OT encryption protocols, SCADA communications, PMU authentication
pqc_replacement: Quantum-safe algorithms for constrained devices, hybrid QKD/PQC
main_source: Smart Energy International / University of Toronto

threat_description: HSM PQC architecture gap: No HSM vendors currently support full PQC architectures despite FIPS 140-3 certification. Average 2+ year certification lag creates window of vulnerability. PQC-ready HSMs expected 2026-2027.
crypto_at_risk: HSM internal cryptographic operations, root of trust firmware, key generation algorithms
pqc_replacement: Crypto4A quantum-safe HSMs, hybrid HSM architectures

threat_description: Healthcare HNDL exposure critical: Only 4% of healthcare operators have encrypted 80%+ of sensitive cloud data. Health records retain sensitivity indefinitely making them prime HNDL targets. 677 major breaches in 2024 exposed 182M+ individuals globally.
crypto_at_risk: RSA, ECC, TLS protocols protecting EHRs, HIPAA-compliant encryption
main_source: Thales 2025 Data Threat Report Healthcare Edition
